text: - [Narrator] Hello everyone.

In this Tech Talk I'm
going to introduce you

to a new feature in AWS Transfer
Family, SFTP connectors.
Before I discuss the new feature,

let's review the primary
use cases customers enable
with Transfer Family.
The core use case is simple file sharing.
Customers use Transfer Family's fully

managed endpoints to
provide access to data,

stored in AWS storage over
common protocols like SFTP.

This allows customers
to easily share files
with external third party users
or applications without refactoring.

When customers formalize
this third party data sharing
into a centralized business function
and designate a central team responsible

for administering those
exchanges, they often refer

to this practice as managed
file transfer, or MFT.
Customers use AWS Transfer Family to build
and deliver cloud native MFT
for their businesses and partners.
Finally, with the addition of AS2 in 2022

customers are now able to
exchange EDI documents used
for transactional business to business

or B2B communications with
their business partners.
AWS Transfer Families fully managed

AS2 Service provides a
modern interface for EDI
enabling customers to simplify business

critical functions such as
supply chain operations.
It was AS2 where Transfer Family first
introduced the concept of a connector

which enables customers
to use a fully managed

service to enable outbound
workflows with their partners.

Now we have extended our
outbound capabilities to
include the SFTP protocol.
SFTP connectors is a fully managed service
which simplifies copying data
between remote SFTP servers and Amazon S3.
Some customers refer
to these workflows as client operations.
These types of fully managed SFTP client
operations are most frequently utilized

as part of a managed file
transfer architecture.

When an MFT architecture
includes both server
and client operations, we call
that a bi-directional MFT workflow

and with the introduction
of SFTP connectors,

AWS Transfer Family now
supports bi-directional MFT

by providing both a fully
managed listening endpoint
for SFTP, FTPS, or FTP,

as well as a fully managed
connector for outbound SFTP.
MFT customers are now

able to receive files
from third party users

or automated pipelines over
these common protocols.
Process these files to refine them

or create new information
and distribute this data
to external third parties over SFTP.

Additionally, SFTP connectors
support retrieve operations,
which means a connector can connect

to an external SFTP server
and pull a file to be stored
in your Amazon S3 buckets.
Driving automated pipelines

like enriching your data
lake with third party data.
SFTP connectors will scale on your behalf,

meaning you do not need
to do the heavy lifting

of determining decision
points like what type
of compute platform to use
or how to build in AZ level redundancy.

SFTP connectors is easy
to set up and integrates
with other AWS services offering an API,

which can be integrated
with your code pipelines
and your preferred scheduling tools.

As a fully managed
service, SFTP connectors
maintain certain compliances based

on industry standards
like HIPAA, preventing you

from having to not only
build your own solution

but ensure its compliance
on your own as well.
And SFTP connectors are cost efficient.

You will only pay for a
connector when you use it

and based on the data you
move with the service.

The real value of SFTP
connectors has realized its scale
when you reduce the burden
of managing and maintaining infrastructure

in complex code and
automate these pipelines,

saving time for your operations
and development personnel.
While using this fully managed service
to enable key pipelines to deliver data
into your S3 buckets, you break
down the need for data silos.

From S3, your data can be
incorporated into AI, analytics,
data lake and many other workloads.
This fully managed service will log all
of its activity into CloudWatch, ensuring
that you have the complete logs you need
for your compliance and governance.

All of this value connectors
provides while only requiring

that you pay for the
service when you use it

and based on how much
data you move with it.

There are no minimum
commitments or ongoing fees.
Let's quickly review the architecture
of transfer SFTP connectors

and then we will discuss
how to get started.
An SFTP connector is configured
for access to a remote SFTP server.

The connector configuration
holds all the information

necessary to make a connection
to the remote server

to either retrieve files
from the source or send files
to the destination.
The files sent or retrieved are persisted

in Amazon S3 buckets
where they can be used

by your critical pipeline,
such as analytics,

machine learning, persisted
as a long-term archive,

or distributed out to external
subscribers as content.
There are many more use cases.
So let's get started with SFTP connectors.
We support deploying SFTP connectors
with cloud formation or RCLI and API,

but a connector is also easily
configured in our console.
Within the AWS Transfer Family console

and the connections menu, you
can select Create Connector.

We now support creating a
connector over either AS2 or SFTP.
When you select SFTP and select next,

you will be able to store
a URL for your connector
which may be a host name or an IP address.

You are also welcome to
use a colon at the end

and specify a custom port
for this external server.

Additionally, you'll want to
select a role which has access

to the location in S3
where you want to send
or retrieve your data to or from,
as well as a secret and secrets manager

which will hold the
authentication details,
more on that in a second.

Additionally, you can
select the logging role
which allows all of the activities
of your new connector to be logged

in CloudWatch for later
auditing and reporting.

Additionally, on the connector
configuration console,
you are able to store the host key

for your external server
to ensure your connector
is reaching the right source
and apply any tags you might want to
for your connector as well.
Finally, you're able to select

or create a secret from
AWS Secrets Manager.
This secret will be the source

for any login credentials
needed to authenticate
to the external server.

If you click on the dropdown,
you'll be allowed to choose

from an existing list of
secrets in your account

or if you haven't previously
stored this secret

you can link directly
to store a new secret
in another window.

Your secret will be stored
as another kind of secret

and should contain a username
as well as either a password,
a key, or both.

SFTP connectors will
support authentication flows

for keys, passwords, or keys
combined with passwords,

based on your external
servers login requirements.
Once you have configured the details
of your secret and selected next
you'll be able to give your secret a name.
We recommend a naming prefix such

as AWS transfer connector
to be able to easily

identify the secret in your
connector configuration console.
Once you apply a name and select next,

your secret will be available
in the secrets console.
If you're adhering
to the concept of least privileged access,
you'll want to select your secret
and update the role you created
for your SFTP connector to include only

the specific ARN of the
secret that contains
that connector's authentication details.
With your secret created,

you'll have all the
information you need to
create your SFTP connector.
So SFTP connectors will enable outbound
push architectures.

One customer example includes
a payment application
which uses a transfer family SFTP server

to upload its transaction
details at the end of each day.

In this use case, the incoming
file needs to be compressed

and encrypted, and pushed
to an external SFTP server
in a partner's network.
Utilizing AWS Transfer Family workflows,

automated file processing
operations are enabled
on the transfer server to
both compress and encrypt the file.
This file is in stage to a specific prefix
and an S3 bucket where an S3 event is

configured to call an AWS
Lambda function on put.
This Lambda contains a low-code call
to the API for connectors

which makes the external
connection to the partner
SFTP server

and pushes the newly
staged file automatically.

SFTP connectors also enable
inbound pull architectures.
In this customer example,

a pharma company is retrieving
clinical research data
from an external partners SFTP server
and storing it in S3.

In this architecture, the
customer uses an event

bridge schedule to periodically
call a lambda function
and this lambda function retrieves a list
of files from a DynamoDB table

and calls an SFTP connector
to retrieve the files
and store them in S3.

In this customer's use
case, it was desired

that a notification be sent
when a new file was staged.

So an additional S3
event was configured to
call a lambda, which sent a notification

to an SNS topic when
a new file was written
to the configured prefix.

These are just some of the
workloads you can enable

with AWS Transfer
Family's SFTP connectors.

To learn more or get started
with AWS Transfer Family

please visit our site where
you can find more content

about our service, our use
cases, and SFTP connectors.
Thank you for viewing our Tech Talk

to learn more about AWS Transfer
Family and SFTP connectors.
